Question_1.Context: The paper discusses the preparation of NdFeB powders filled polymeric matrix (PEEK) and their use in 3D printing to produce high-performance magnets. The influence of the filler on the main thermomechanical properties of the resulting composites was evaluated.
Question_1.Question: What is one possible solution proposed in the paper to address the poor corrosion resistance of NdFeB magnets?
Question_1.A: Development of innovative polymeric composite magnetic materials
Question_1.B: Increasing the filler amount in the composite
Question_1.C: Using a different type of magnetic filler
Question_1.D: Reducing the amount of PEEK in the composite
Question_1.Source: One possible solution is the development of innovative polymeric composite magnetic materials.

Question_2.Context: The paper mentions that the PEEK- NdFeB filaments were produced with three percentages of filler amount (25, 50, and 75 wt%).
Question_2.Question: What were the three percentages of filler amount used in the production of PEEK-NdFeB filaments?
Question_2.Source: PEEK-NdFeB filaments were produced with three percentages of filler amount (i.e. 25, 50, and 75 wt%).

Question_3.Context: The paper discusses the thermal stability of the printed parts and the effects of the printing process on the material properties.
Question_3.Question: What was observed in the DSC analysis of the printed parts regarding the crystallinity of the first layer compared to the upper layers?
Question_3.A: The first layer had higher crystallinity than the upper layers
Question_3.B: The first layer had lower crystallinity than the upper layers
Question_3.C: The first layer had similar crystallinity to the upper layers
Question_3.D: The first layer had no crystallinity
Question_3.Source: The first layer was found to have a lower degree of crystallinity, reported by the presence of a cold crystallization peak after the glass transition.

Question_4.Context: The paper reports a decrease in thermal stability after printing and discusses the reasons behind this observation.
Question_4.Question: What is one possible reason for the decrease in thermal stability of the printed parts compared to the relevant filaments?
Question_4.A: Higher crystallinity in the printed parts
Question_4.B: Degradation of the PEEK matrix during printing
Question_4.C: Lower filler content in the printed parts
Question_4.D: Improved interlayer adhesion in the printed parts
Question_4.Source: A decrease in thermal stability after printing was observed, attributed to some degree of degradation occurring to the polymer during the printing.

Question_5.Context: The paper discusses the tensile testing of the 3D composite printed parts and the mechanical properties observed.
Question_5.Question: What effect did the presence of irregular edges on the particles have on the mechanical properties of the printed parts?
Question_5.Source: The presence of irregular edges on the particles acted as initiation sites for cracks, leading to a decrease in tensile strength.

Question_6.Context: The paper reports the magnetic properties of the printed samples and discusses the discrepancy between the measured and expected values.
Question_6.Question: What was one possible explanation provided for the discrepancy between the measured and expected magnetic properties of the printed parts?
Question_6.A: Presence of porosity in the samples
Question_6.Source: The discrepancy among the measured Br and the expected values is due to the presence of porosities in the sample.

Question_7.Context: The paper discusses the thermal degradation of the PEEK matrix during the printing process and its impact on the magnetic properties of the printed parts.
Question_7.Question: What was observed in the EDX map analysis of the magnetic particles contained in the printed samples?
Question_7.C: Low Nd and Fe content and high oxygen content
Question_7.Source: The Nd and Fe content was found to be low and the oxygen content high, suggesting the formation of species coming from oxidation reaction.

Question_8.Context: The paper discusses the coercitivity of the printed samples and the differences observed between PEEK_25NdFeB and PEEK_50NdFeB.
Question_8.Question: What was one observed difference in the coercitivity between PEEK_25NdFeB and PEEK_50NdFeB printed samples?
Question_8.C: No difference in coercitivity between the two samples
Question_8.Source: Coercitivity was found to be much lower in PEEK_50NdFeB printed parts with respect to PEEK_25NdFeB samples.

Question_9.Context: The paper discusses the feasibility of using PEEK-NdFeB composite filaments in 3D printing for high-performance magnets.
Question_9.Question: What was the energy product value observed for PEEK_25NdFeB printed parts?
Question_9.Source: Energy products of 130 J/m3 for PEEK_25NdFeB demonstrated the feasibility of the magnetic 3D printed composite with PEEK.

Question_10.Context: The paper concludes by discussing the need for further optimization of the printing process to develop magnets suitable for space applications.
Question_10.Question: What was identified as a major finding regarding the printed samples in the conclusion of the paper?
Question_10.Source: The major finding was considered the presence of a not negligible amount of porosity and, in the case of PEEK_50NdFeB sample, the lack of filler orientation.
